s.text: He helped his clients eat and find a warm bed.
To reread Grisham--in particular, recent Grisham--is to be struck by how completely he is devoting his celebrity to the articulation of a passionate and decidedly unfashionable liberalism.
Compared to, say, David Baldacci ( Absolute Power ) or Joseph Finder ( The Zero Hour ), his plotting is pedestrian.
He joins a tiny public-interest group representing the poor and downtrodden.
When it comes to character, he can do hard-working, naive, up-from-the-middle-class associates in their late 20s.

In The Street Lawyer , Grisham sheds whatever lingering attachments he may have had to the frivolity of his genre and emerges as a moralist--a skilled and worthy practitioner of the largely forgotten art of socially redeeming fiction.
Tom Clancy is just as easy.
This has never been more true, though, than in Grisham's new book.
I helped my clients swallow up competitors so they could add more zeros to the bottom line, and for this I would become rich.
